clinical_study.brief_title: Proportional Dose of Sublingual Fentanyl Tablet Based on Daily Opioid Requirement
clinical_study.official_title: Proportional Dose of Sublingual Fentanyl Tablet Based on Daily Opioid Requirement Versus Intravenous PCA for Breakthrough Cancer Pain: A Prospective, Randomized, Open Label, Non Inferiority Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Proportional dose of sublingual fentanyl tablet (Narco®) based on daily opioid requirement versus intravenous PCA for breakthrough cancer pain: A prospective, randomized, open-label, noninferiority trial.

detailed_description.textblock: Based on the previous around-the-clock analgesic demand compared to IV PCA in cancer pain patients to prepare the basis for the administration of fentanyl sublingual tablets with an initial dose.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in 11-point scale NRS pain score
primary_outcome.description: Change in pain score compared to baseline Score '0' representing one pain extreme (e.g. "no pain") to '10' representing the other pain extreme (e.g. "pain as bad as you can imagine" or "worst pain imaginable"

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in 11-point scale NRS pain score
secondary_outcome.description: Change in pain score compared to baseline Score '0' representing one pain extreme (e.g. "no pain") to '10' representing the other pain extreme (e.g. "pain as bad as you can imagine" or "worst pain imaginable"

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 19-80
- Cancer pain
- Admission for the control of cancer pain or consultation for the treatment of cancer pain
- Stable vital sign
- ECOG status ≤ 3 for more than 1 or 2 months
- Opioid-tolerant state
- No history of using sublingual fentanyl
Exclusion Criteria:
- Noncancer pain
- Opioid naive
- baseline NRS pain score> 4
- Current using sublingual fentanyl
- Difficult to assess cancer pain
- no evidence of disease(cancer)
- Planned surgical resection of cancer
- Allergy to fentanyl
- Severe renal and/or liver function
- Severe respiratory depression or uncontrolled COPD
